The new charity will manage the National Heritage Collection, which includes Stonehenge and Dover Castle. The government currently contributes £22m annually towards the collection. The new official body, which will also advise on planning, has a working name of the National Heritage Protection Service. The new charity will still be called English Heritage and the 420 sites in the National Heritage Collection - which include London's Kenwood House, and Charles Darwin's home in Kent - will remain in public ownership. Government funding for the charity will be tapered down from 2015 eventually to nothing, meaning it will have more freedom than now to generate income from commercial activities and philanthropic donations. Representatives from rugby union, rugby league, American football, ice hockey, and Australian rules football met in Dublin on Thursday. Earlier this year a panel headed by former Wallaby Paul Gallen and British referee Tim Riley warned that there was no place in the modern game for players who take illegal drugs.

The meeting also raised issues such as concussion and concussion awareness. It was agreed that the IRB should consider introducing laws that ensure players are kept under medical supervision during matches.

In the IRB's 2016 Annual Report, senior vice-president John Fahey said that in most countries in the world high performance athletes "frequently use performance-enhancing drugs". Fahey said that the IRB was aware of the risks associated with a player using any drug except a therapeutic substance.

IRB guidelines said that "players who use substances [including illegal drugs] during competitions are at increased risk of concussion or brain injury, and are more likely to develop neurological problems in later life."
